review: Really torn on this book. Everyone claims it is the authors masterpiece and it is a very good book but once again I have problems with how the book isReally torn on this book. Everyone claims it is the authors masterpiece and it is a very good book but once again I have problems with how the book is portrayed. It was the first of a trilogy of books that concentrated on Edward Feathers - Old Filth - with book two being from his wifes point of view and book 3 being more revelations about the couple.Filth refers to Failed in London Try Hong Kong and one is led to believe that Old Filth failed as a solicitor in London and was a success is Hong Kong. Well, he was a success is Hong Kong but very little of the book relates to how he became a success in Hong Kong and how he ever really failed in London - so the book just fell flat for me in that regard.What we do have is a book that is about Feathers recollections of his childhood in Malay, being sent to Wales, being put in private schools, his aunts and his illnesses as he floats back and forth from London to Singapore and back.To me this book and the trilogy reminds me of a British version of Mr. and Mrs. Bridge, but not nearly as well written and concise of a story as this book wanders back and forth from childhood, to old age, to events in between and some of the longer chapters really dragged for me.On the whole I really say that book 2 and 3 of this trilogy will not be books that I will be reading after a disappointing effort in this first book....more

title: In the Company of Cheerful Ladies        (No. 1 Ladies' Detective Agency, #6)
author: McCall Smith, Alexander*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Things have gotten better in this, the 6th book of the No. 1 Ladies Detective Agency. Some of my frustrations of book 5 got resolved and there was morThings have gotten better in this, the 6th book of the No. 1 Ladies Detective Agency. Some of my frustrations of book 5 got resolved and there was more mystery and more matters that held our attention in this book. It began early with Mma. Ramotswe having a feeling there was an intruder in her home, and then there was the episode with the the pumpkin that mysteriously arrived on her porch. Mma. Makutsi plays a prominent role, once again in the book and we are also introduced to two new characters, Mr. Polopetsi and Mr. Phuti Radiphuti (maybe the best name I have heard in a while). Nothing too serious or exciting happened in the book and yet it is a quite satisfying read, as small matters now begin to consume the Agency. A person from Mma. Ramotswe's past shows up, Mr. J.L.B. Matekoni has tenant issues and Mma. Makutsi takes dancing lessons. Daily life really encroaches on the Agency and no matter how big or small, the No. 1 Ladies Detective Agency is ready to tackle any case - even if we do have to wait until almost the very end to find out how that pumpkin got onto Mma. Ramotswe's verandah. The more you read this series, the more these characters become fleshed out and by the end of the book you are ready for the next book in the series to see how your friends at the No. 1 Ladies Detective Agency are faring in the day to day adventures of life in Botswana....more

title: Valiant Ambition: George Washington, Benedict Arnold, and the Fate of the American Revolution        (The American Revolution Series)
author: Philbrick, Nathaniel*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My first book written by Nathaniel Philbrick. A very good effort on a very important and also complicated topic - Washington and Benedict Arnold. The My first book written by Nathaniel Philbrick. A very good effort on a very important and also complicated topic - Washington and Benedict Arnold. The book takes us through most of the Revolutionary War and focuses on a lot of Battles or skirmishes that I never was even aware of! The battles are supplemented by many maps of the battlefields and fortifications and there are a lot of sketches and drawings in the photo section of the book that allows the reader to put faces to the names.We see Washington as a charismatic leader, who struggles to overcome his military desire to fight head on battles with the British - and we see that at the beginning of the war he loses most every one of those encounters. He develops of strategy of a Defensive War, a war in which the sheer size and topography of the US will allow him to overcome the vastly superior British forces, and as long as he sticks with that, combined with some lightning attacks and Battles against the British he does well. On the other hand we have Arnold who is not a great military planner, but who also has the ability to grasp situations on the battlefield and who shows no fear of life or limb and is the opposite of Washington in that Defensive wars are not in his makeup and he prefers to go head on and wins so many of these battles. But despite his victories he is a seriously flawed character, a man who feels he is always overlooked and who is owed more by his country that they give him. Even his lack of a promotion to a Major General is a sore spot for him, and when he gets that promotion he is not happy since he is not given seniority over other Major Generals appointed before him.Arnold loves money, power and women and they are his downfall. He is constantly persecuted - many times without justification and his anger is always simmering beneath the surface. He is a favorite of Washington, who knows how good he is on the battlefield, but who also sees that Arnold is his own worst enemy.This is a very good effort and one that everyone should read as it is filled with many insights into our founding fathers, the British adversaries and the sheer luck that America had in the Revolutionary War. I came away amazed at how many battles, or events unfolded just by happenstance and how the course of history turned on such things. I also enjoyed the analysis of the author that Arnold's treason actually helped solidify our resolve to win the war and made people aware of the need to be united as a country to win and now continue down the road as 13 independent states, everyone doing as they wanted. At one point the one state militia's enlistment ended the night before a major battle and the head of that states militia and his men just left at the stroke of midnight. Chaos and confusion reigned in the early days of the Revolution and it was not until all these battles and events played themselves out that the country eventually became a truly United States of America....more

title: The Broken Shore        (Broken Shore, #1)
author: Temple, Peter
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 3.5* for this book. After listening to Nancy Pearl rave about this book on her podcast I decided to give this book a try. There is no doubt that Peter3.5* for this book. After listening to Nancy Pearl rave about this book on her podcast I decided to give this book a try. There is no doubt that Peter Temple is a good writer, but this book was hard for me to follow with few people having full names, action jumping all over the place and a plot that for some reason was very easy for me to figure out. While this is a very good book I cannot for the life of me figure out why Pearl slobbers over this. It was a slog for the first third of the book and then things finally began to move along at a quick clip which I must admit helped raise the books rating. So much is left unsaid in this book, character development is nil and while it is good to read a detective story from a different country and different point of view, it is not something that makes me want to read more Peter Temple in the future.Now a word about Aborigines. Australia has a racial problem, and the aborigines are not exactly loved over there and that comes out big time in this book. But what I find particularly interesting is some very "sophisticated and sensitive" readers and ers have expressed shock and almost disdain for books like Huckleberry Finn and the Little House series by Laura Ingles Wilder due to their depiction of blacks and Native American Indians, those same people seem not to care one iota about the way the aborigines are depicted and spoken of in this book. Lots of derogatory language and references to them in this book and those same "sophisticated and sensitive" people shrug it off. Apparently it is OK to do this with books about foreign lands and to be self-righteous about these US books. I say hogwash! Listen, and I am not going off on a rant here, books are windows into ourselves and our history and just because something might not be politically correct today, does not mean that it has to be trashed and spoken of with disdain. If you are one of those "sophisticated and sensitive" readers than this book might make you squirm, but The Broken Shore does depict the racial rift in Australia and for that I must really give the author kudos. We do not see or hear about this that much over here in the US and this book helps give me a look into the issue. Language on the whole can be "detective" crude in this book and some of that crudeness seems a bit overdone. The ending of the book is good but not great and while Peter Temple may be a good writer (by the way there are no chapter divisions in this book), I doubt that I will seek out his other works. Glad that I heard about this book from Nancy Pearl, but I think her lavish praise of the book is just a bit over the top!...more

It takes almost 1/3 of the book before we even get into a detective case and that is well and good in a 350-400 page book, but when they are a mere 200 pages it shows that the cases are really on the back burner of the book. We continue to learn about Botswana, but the time has come for the author to stop repeating the characters history in each and every book. How many times must we hear about Note Makoti, Mma. Ramotswe's first husband, the background on Mma. Makutsi at the Botswana Secretarial school, etc. etc. I have read where the author is prodigious in his writing and I can understand why, if all you are going to do is repeat the same history in book, after book, after book!The detective case is weak and the only fun part of this book was the Parachute jump for Charity, in all of its machinations. We also get a very satisfactory ending with regards to Mma. Ramotswe and Mr. J.L.B. Matekoni, but other than this the author has pretty much let down his loyal readers.I know, I know, these books are published about one year apart and I have read the first five in short order, but any fan of the No. 1 Ladies Detective Agency knows the format, the history and most of the rather simplistic plots and cases that resolved. The time has come to shake up this series and hopefully book 6 will be a better effort. ...more

title: The Kalahari Typing School for Men        (No. 1 Ladies' Detective Agency, #4)

review: Another solid effort in the No. 1 Ladies Detective Series, as these books continue to delve into its characters and manages to use this as a way to haAnother solid effort in the No. 1 Ladies Detective Series, as these books continue to delve into its characters and manages to use this as a way to have them involved in the new cases. So far, most of the cases are cute and involve a lot of moral detecting, but the time has come for Mma. Ramotswe and Mma. Makusti even though it was short-lived, as she also branches out by opening the Mens Typing School. Mma. Makutsi is a great character and almost a more enjoyable one then the lead character Mms Ramotswe. You do not want to miss the one part where they all go to church to support their one apprentice - it is hilarious and is the funniest thing that has been written to date in this series. It is obvious that the author loved Botswana and has transferred that love onto his main character Mma. Ramotswe. And as in all the prior books, by the end all the cases and moral dilemmas are resolved by the end of the book and we are left with only one question? When will Mma. Ramotswe and Mr. J.L.B. title: The Secret of Santa Vittoria: A Novel
author: Crichton, Robert
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Really torn on this book, as I remember the movie that was made from this - a movie that was a huge box office disappointment! Maybe it is because I aReally torn on this book, as I remember the movie that was made from this - a movie that was a huge box office disappointment! Maybe it is because I am Italian, maybe it is because the sites in the book all come from the region of my ancestry - Le Marche on the Adriatic Coast - and maybe it is because of the fact that this is an older book based on WW2. I wanted to like the book that is sort of classified as a comedy but at the same time there are vast parts of this book that deal with the horror of war that, while realistic, really gave me a different impression on the book.The basic premise is that the town of Santa Vittoria is a great wine growing and producing area, and is the wine used to make vermouth. After the US invasion of Italy the Germans move into the area and a small group of 8 or 9 soldiers are told to take the town and get the wine. The town, after the fall of the Fascist government, elected a new mayor who is charitably described as a Sicilian clown, except he is a much deeper thinker than they realize and he does things to help the town including hiding the wine. This is a book about occupation and resistance, about the Italians appearing dumber than the Germans and yet have outwitted them the entire time. Seen as that there is definitely amusement in the book.However, the scenes of torture by the SS, sacrificial citizens unwittingly being led to torture, a village hostage who is left tied up in the village square before being killed, the substitution of another citizen for sacrificial death, etc. all is a lot more than I expected and to me the book drags through these parts, as the citizens are forced to do all of this to protect their One Million bottles of wine. Not that realistic that wine is more important that people and dignity, and dignity is what is lacking in this book as the Italians are made to look like fools and in the end the German occupiers are made to suffer the same fate.Also, cannot stand the character Tufa who plays an important part in the book and certain storylines appear not to have been successfully tied up by the end of the book.A fast read, and at times a fun read, but not one I would really recommend....more

title: Morality for Beautiful Girls        (No. 1 Ladies' Detective Agency, #3)
author: McCall Smith, Alexander*

review: I gave this book a 4**** because I have joined the legions of fans of the No. 1 Ladies Detective Agency. This 3rd book in the series is quite a bit diI gave this book a 4**** because I have joined the legions of fans of the No. 1 Ladies Detective Agency. This 3rd book in the series is quite a bit different than the first two, one of the big differences being the lack of dialogue in the book when compared to the first two. In this book we learn more about Philosophies of life, Botswana traditions and backgrounds and issues with the main characters. The cases are a lot less challenging, in my opinion, and we are really given an in depth look at Mma. Makutsi who began as a minor character and now has become quite the major character in the series as she has gone from a secretary to an Assistant Detective to now a new position as Assistant Garage Manager. She handles a big case with a big fee all by herself and it is fun to see her character develop. Mma. Ramotswe is involved in her own case out of the area, as well as being preoccupied with the two orphans who came into their lives in Book 2, and an illness that has befallen her fiance Mr. J.L.B. Matekoni,and this propels Mma. Makusti into the forefront. She gains the respect of the garage apprentices and proves herself a valuable asset to both businesses.it is another fun book, but not quite as rollicking as the first two. I would definitely not start the series with this book, since it is a definite build on the first two and character development propels the saga forward. It is fun to read, it is delightful to follow and since I am reading them consecutively it really is great to be able to quickly follow all the action of the series. This book is only 227 pages in length and is a fast read, and I just began book 4 and that one is only 192 pages, so these are great books to either get from the library or by use of the free e-reader delivery system from the library. As I remain in Romania, I am so very happy to be transported to Botswana on a daily basis with the No. 1 Ladies Detective Agency!...more

title: Ghettoside: A True Story of Murder in America
author: Leovy, Jill
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What a fine book and what an expose of crime in LA, black on black murder and how America seems to dismiss this phenomenon. The first thing that hit mWhat a fine book and what an expose of crime in LA, black on black murder and how America seems to dismiss this phenomenon. The first thing that hit me was a quote from a detective who commented that one Saturday the LA Times ran a banner front page headline on how a rocket attack in Beirut killed 6 people. He went on to sat that same weekend there were 9 homocides of black youths in LA and not one mention of this was made in the LA papers, TV or radio. One understands what that community feels they are undervalued in the system.The book is basically about the homocide of Bryant Tennelle who was walking home one day and was shot in the head and killed. Making it more newsworthy was the fact that Bryant's father was a Homocide Detective and that the family lived in the less than desirable area of LA and had been a beacon of stability and help for that community. We first are introduced to the players - from the victim, his family, the lead detective and others who were involved in the investigation. The 2nd part of the book deals with investigative work and the trial. Despite being a retired attorney I found this part a bit tedious, and the author kept moving from one murder investigation to another - there are so many murders in the "South of the 10" region that the detectives work multiple murders at one time and I assume the purpose of all of these details is to let us see what really goes on, but to me it sort of took away from the book. Bryant Tennelle's case sort of became secondary to the story she was telling - despite the fact that is really is a fascinating story. We see what happens in Gangs, with witnesses, with the community and how hard it is to get anyone to talk about the crime for fear of reprisals and then when they get to a hearing or trial they recant their testimony and have to have it impeached. This is an eye-opening book in so many different ways but you are glad that there are so many hard working detectives trying to solve these murders, even though there is a group identified as the 40-percenters who have a much lower success rate.However, I feel that the books premise falls apart as the author tried to put a sociological spin on the black crime statistics in LA. She goes back to slavery, Jim Crow laws, double standards of enforcement in the past and in other cities, and the issue of economic stagnation in the black community. I agree with her points of economic stagnation, but are any of the reasons she gives sufficient for people to randomly kill other people? This is what I have trouble believing. We also see the stories that many of the gang members may have been the youngest children in their families or have some sort of ADD or ADHD disorder. In my mind there has to be a lot of change in the thinking of life and the destruction of murder. It is a major problem in not just LA but throughout inner cities, and while official police policies many times deal with prevention - black crime will not stop until there are major changes in attitudes.And to close with an even more frightening statistic - from the day the Bryant Tennelle was murdered until the day of the trial 2 years later, over 546 more black men were killed in LA. Something has to change and I thank the author for bringing this issue to our attention....more

title: City of Scoundrels: The 12 Days of Disaster That Gave Birth to Modern Chicago

review: Now this was a fun book for me - even though it covered a very difficult time period: Summer of 1919 in Chicago. First of all a shout out to Carly at Now this was a fun book for me - even though it covered a very difficult time period: Summer of 1919 in Chicago. First of all a shout out to Carly at LitWit podcast. She did not recommend this book, but another one by Gary Krist and that got me searching the library e-book shelves. They had this book and it was a super enjoyable and fast non-fiction read.Set in the summer of 1919 this book documents all that happened that summer: Aviation disaster, race riots, Red scare, child kidnapping, corrupt Mayor running for reelection, etc. Krist is one of this new breed of non-fiction writers who write as if it is a novel. Well written and superbly researched, this is a book for anyone who wants to learn a bit of US history, learn about Chicago, learn about some amazingly colorful figures, learn about the press and just try and recreate all that was happening in Chicago almost 100 years ago. The author does take a quick shot or two at current day Chicago and Illinois politics, but it is 1919 that draws our focus and the vice and corruption that was Chicago at the dawn of the Jazz Age.I big thumbs up to this and a great book for those who do not love non-fiction, but who enjoy a good story. One thing about Chicago, it may have been corrupt but it certainly was a very good story!...more

title: The No. 1 Ladies' Detective Agency
author: McCall Smith, Alexander*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Probably a 3.5* for detective novels. When I began this year with my personal reading goals in place I had no idea that one of my stops would be BotswProbably a 3.5* for detective novels. When I began this year with my personal reading goals in place I had no idea that one of my stops would be Botswana with The No. 1 Ladies' Detective Agency! I had heard of this series and had thought that at some time I might give it a try and then, once again, thanks to all of you on Goodreads I kept seeing people reading this book and so I thought I should give it a try and so I logged onto my libraries webpage, searched, pointed and clicked and here it came to me in Romania! A very fast moving book filled with some fun characters, led by MMa. Ramotswe who decided to take her inheritance and open a detective agency. She is large, smart woman and here in Volume 1 we are introduced to her, Botswana, southern Africa and some of the friends and clients that I am sure will inhabit future books in this series. Is this a real brain teaser sort of mystery series - Not really. Is MMa. Ramotswe a very good detective? No overly. She gets results but these are early career cases and I am sure she will grow in future adventures. She is intuitive and has an uncanny way of solving mysteries and yet there are times you know that she is a novice and some of the case resolutions fall into her lap and others I am not sure that she really solves, but in the end her style of sleuthing works perfectly for where she is. This book is a super-fast read and is filled with about 10 or so cases that she "solves" one of which begins early in the book and we have to wait until near the end to find a resolution, but that is realistic because not all detectives work on one single case to the exclusion of others. I am currently in the midst of some long books set in England and this was a great way to break up that reading - since it is such a fast read one can quickly get back to other books - if I could make one suggestion to my fellow readers it would be to either get this book at the library or through your libraries free e-delivery system. The book is enjoyable but I would not go out and purchase it either in paperback or on my e-reader, it is just not that spectacular a book that it is worth you hard earned $$, but it certainly a book that is a fun read and will fill you with pleasure, and the desire to start Volume 2 in the near future!...more

A mention here or there but most all of this is about those who went back and forth between the US and Mexico and how black slaves could pass themselves off in the US as Mexicans. It was a really informative book with regards to societal situations in the 1800's. What I gleaned from the book about William Ellis is about Zero. Nothing is really known about his early life and for allegedly being a millionaire he died with huge debts and only $15,000. He seemed more of a con artist or "trickster" as the book calls him near the end. He never really worked but was an idea man. Settling Mexico with former slaves, supplying slaves to work on plantations in Mexico, etc. None of this really worked out. And so I am left with a very incomplete story of the man but a great history of society. ...more

title: The Pickwick Papers
author: Dickens, Charles
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I loved this book and am now proud to proclaim myself a Pickwickian!! For years I shied away from Dickens and his novels. But a few years ago I began I loved this book and am now proud to proclaim myself a Pickwickian!! For years I shied away from Dickens and his novels. But a few years ago I began with A Tale of Two Cities and loved it, despite its overuse of commas and semi-colons! So I decided to give Dickens a try and bought the first five of his novels in paperback form and his entire collection on Kindle. For a year the books just sat on the shelf and stared at me, as did books by Victor Hugo and Dumas. I kept saying I was going to start reading Dickens and finally the time came. The Pickwick Papers became my summer reading, as it is a easy book to put down and read others in between, but as time wore on Pickwick's adventures claimed more of my time until about 4 days ago I decided the time had come to finish it before Autumn began and I have accomplished that!!This is Dickens first novel and you can really see the serialized nature of the book as 2-3 chapters were published in his monthly paper. It is a humorous book with many passages causing me to laugh out loud. His characters are great and they are an oddball variety of people who either go with or whom he meets on his two-year trek to discover England. Pickwick had been a rather unwordly person, and who sees the world though almost child-like eyes. Good-hearted and always ready to see the best in everyone, this book is a collection of events during his travels. It is early Dickens but you can already see the keen eye he casts upon so many aspects of British life and society. You can see his disdain for lawyers, his shocking descriptions of debtors prison, his portrayal of doctors all in this book. Yet, wherever he goes he finds an adventure. Probably the weakest parts of the book, for me, is when he throws in totally unrelated tales that he hears of things that have absolutely nothing to do with the book. Some are good but many are just so-so and I could have done without. My favorite of these stories was of the Goblins that stole a Sexton and was related on Christmas Eve. Good story. There are loads of fun and funny characters, there are many scenes that make you just want to laugh out loud until the very last page where we are left with an elderly Pickwick now living in London. It was with a tear that I finished this book, as I felt I had made friends with Mr. Pickwick and his fellow travelers and companions. But it also put me in a mood to read more Dickens, including A Christmas Carol which I have yet to read in my 63 years here on earth. And so I come to the end of this  and give a hale and hearty cheer to my good friend Samuel Pickwick, I will never forget you or your adventures and you have kindled in my heart and spirit a feeling of goodness and revelry that has been missing for the past few years. Farewell Pickwick, we part as friends and say goodbye all the while knowing that you have added one more loyal and dedicated member to The Pickwick Society. Friends and Pickwickians to the end!!...more

author: George, Nina*

review: Well my dear wife ended up in tears by the end of the book. I thought the book was just OK. It certainly was not what we expected - advertised as a boWell my dear wife ended up in tears by the end of the book. I thought the book was just OK. It certainly was not what we expected - advertised as a book seller who could see into peoples souls and give them the perfect book (it happened about 2 times in the very beginning), as well as that same person leaving Paris and heading south (that happened but one certainly did not see all the closeness of everyone).This is a book with flowery, descriptive prose that may appeal to a lot of book lovers who enjoy books about bookstores and books, but it really is about learning to love. We have three main male characters all of whom are in various stages of grief and looking for love - all for a very long time, some with women and one from their father. Two set off from Paris and pick up a 3rd and that is where we see the little adventure that is in the book. We put the book aside for about 3 weeks and it got better but those last 5 or 6 chapters, for me, were like pulling teeth. But my wife was caught up in the emotion of the book. Nice book, maybe a book club book, but not anything I would want in my library - get it from the public library....more

title: Fallen Women
author: Dallas, Sandra
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a combination rating. I read this book to my wife who really enjoyed it and gave it 4****, as for myself I found it no better than a 2** efforThis is a combination rating. I read this book to my wife who really enjoyed it and gave it 4****, as for myself I found it no better than a 2** effort from this author. Having read a few of Dallas's books this one just did little for me. Oh, my wife enjoyed the way the mystery of who killed Lillie Brown was resolved, but to be honest both of us figured it out quite early in the book.Worse yet, I really found few quality characters in this book. I guess Mick the detective was a good character although there is so much left unknown about his surprising background, and the 2nd maid Nellie seems like a sweet enough soul, but that is it. Even her protagonist - Beret (an unusual name for a girl and one we never know why she is called that despite a few hints that the reasoning will be forthcoming) - is a very unlikeable character who does so many stupid things in her attempt to help Mick solve Lillie's death. Worse yet, as she does each and every stupid thing we know it and so does she, as the book is filled with her actions and then her realization that she put herself in a bad situation with no way out. But she always does get out of it, most times in rather far-fetched ways.We learn a lot about prostitutes in Denver and that the author makes a valiant to use French words and unknown language at time to describe things in the beginning of the book. When someone finally calls Lillie a whore that sort of stops the beating around the bush.She ties things up too neatly and to be quite honest there really is no logical reason why two more prostitutes need to die, and the entire Hop Alley cocaine situation just leaves me cold.I have ready about 3 or 4 of her books and this one just falls flat for me. Tallgrass was a fine effort, and I enjoyed Buster Midnight's Cafe and the others, but this just leaves me cold and makes me worry about some of her other efforts....more

Well, at times I felt she was really just plugging herself and her 3 memoirs Gotta worry when a person who is younger than me has already felt she needs to write 3 books about herself (I think her first was sufficient), and her attitude that she "knows" how to write such a book better than anyone else. All in all, this short book could have been about 50 pages shorter and lost none of its potency and I wonder if Mary listened to the advice in her book that a writer can take a page and reduce it by 1/3. review: I am really conflicted about this book. Steinbeck is my favorite author, but this sprawling "family" saga of Salinas just did not click on all cylindeI am really conflicted about this book. Steinbeck is my favorite author, but this sprawling "family" saga of Salinas just did not click on all cylinders for me. While there are some very interesting characters, there are also some dogs for me. Despised/loved the Cathy/Kate character but her demise is sort of hokey. Enjoyed Lee the servant of Adam Trask. Liked Adam in the East but not so much in California. Cal was and OK character who grew on me, but Aron was a too pure and pristine for my tastes. Sam Hamilton was GREAT!! And I guess therein lies my problem, some parts of the story are so good and others just left me feeling cold. But, who else but Steinbeck can give us a History lesson on whorehouses??!! The Hamilton family was by far the more interesting group for me, although he sets up the conflict in the Trask family. Also there is so little interaction between the two families other than Sam giving advice to Adam now and then, as well as a short business deal with Will Hamilton and Cal. I wavered between a 3 & 4**** with that extra star being because I think Steinbeck writes so very well and made some very insightful points throughout the book....more

title: Ancillary Justice        (Imperial Radch, #1)

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I tried, oh yes, I tried! I have not read science fiction since way back in Junior High School in the 60's. But lately I have been hearing a lot aboutI tried, oh yes, I tried! I have not read science fiction since way back in Junior High School in the 60's. But lately I have been hearing a lot about this genre and had no idea where to start, but some research brought me to the first of Ann Leckie's trilogy due to overwhelming number of positive s and awards. It is possible that if I read this at another time I might have been more favorably disposed to the book, but after having read "City of Thieves" about the siege of Stalingrad all the pretend conflict in this book just fell flat. But, for me, it is the dual story lines that drift back and forth in the book and the fact that silly and made up names just kept me more confused than ever. It is a gender neutral book but most all characters are somehow or another all female (I really do not care if a book has all female characters), and it got to the point that it just confused me and I just could not keep everything straight. I will tell you that there was one small page in the book that really hit home. It was when the characters were describing luxury, and how one persons luxury is the result of another persons hard work. The author made a similar point when discussing homes and also how one who is basically raised in the lap of luxury expects that to happen and is entitled to that. I felt that was pretty darn profound for a science fiction book!Sorry for all you Sci-Fi fans out there, unless you can point me to a more organized and coherent book this may very well be my final attempt at this genre....more

title: City of Thieves
author: Benioff, David
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What a great book! Again, a big shoutout to Jenny and Reading Envy podcast where I first heard about this book. Secondly, thank goodness that this booWhat a great book! Again, a big shoutout to Jenny and Reading Envy podcast where I first heard about this book. Secondly, thank goodness that this book was available through the Greenville, SC library through their e-book system. And thirdly, thanks so very much to the internet. Why the internet? Well, it never ceases to amaze me that with a simple point and click things can be delivered to my electronic devices. We take that for granted, but not me. Why not? Well, for the past two weeks I have been in Romania and when I pointed and clicked the book was downloaded to my Kindle reader in Bucharest - utterly amazing!!!!Now the book. A truly fine effort by David Benioff and one in which we are placed right smack in the middle of the siege of Leningrad. This is a story of friendship, survival, love and one of the most amazing tasks that anyone has ever been assigned to handle. The story begins well into the siege and the city (referred to by its citizens as Piter) has run out of all foodstuffs. There is rationing, but what is rationed is pitiful to say the least. Bombing occurs nightly and in the middle of this we are introduced to Lev (a 17-year old who is now on his own in the city) and Koyla (a 20-year old Russian Army soldier). Both of these individuals are thrown together by circumstances and eventually are brought before the commander of the forces of Leningrad. Both fear that their past actions have condemned them to death, but instead of death they are give a task. Find one dozen eggs and deliver them in time for the Commanders daughters wedding, since they are needed for the wedding cake. And thus begins a paring and eventual friendship that takes these two outside of the city limits and through a no-mans land that is filled with misery and sorrow, along with images that haunt both of them as well as us the reader. Eventually the two meet up with a band of resistance fighters and their exploits carry them behind German lines in their quest for the eggs. This short book packs a punch and it is a fast read because I just could not put it down for the last 150 pages! We are left with great characters such as Kolya and Lev, along with Vika a female resistance fighter and ace sniper. The book ends a few years after the war and the author neatly ties up all the threads of the plots in the last two short chapters of the book and does so in such a way that it does not feel contrived or a mere exercise in ending the story. And as an added bonus, the book has a last line that (to me) is one of the best I have read!I also was able to keep my wife interested in the plot and story, as she kept asking what was happening and when I finished reading the book and then telling her how the last 50 pages ended she looked at me and said, "What a great book" and her words are those that I began this  with. Thanks to all for this great read, and while many women may not like war novels, this is certainly one that I can recommend to one and all, male or female. It is a great read, in my opinion, and one that can and should be read by everyone....more

title: In the Unlikely Event
author: Blume, Judy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Let me begin by saying that I have never read any of Judy Blume's books previously. As a man, I tend to shy away from the genre in which she has becomLet me begin by saying that I have never read any of Judy Blume's books previously. As a man, I tend to shy away from the genre in which she has become very famous. But I have to once again give a great deal of thanks to my new Goodreads friends for recommending this book. I absolutely enjoyed it and I learned so much about a 60-day period in US history that I had never heard of in the past. The book revolves around the city of Elizabeth, NJ which is right next to the Newark Airport, and back in 1957-58 there were a series of 3 different airplane crashes that occurred there, all of which caused death and destruction, all of which made a profound influence on the lives of the many people who lived there. Judy Blume lived in Elizabeth, NJ and as a small child she grew up knowing about these incidents and used that personal background to give us a very insightful look into the crashes and families involved or peripherally involved with these crashes. A very well written book, one that uses well over 20 characters and 4 families to tell the story. At first it is a bit confusing to keep everyone and every relationship straight, but you eventually settle in and there are a few main characters, a few semi-main characters and a lot of background stories.The people involved have witnessed the crash, or have had a loved one die in the crash, one character even was a hero in saving people from a burning wreckage of the 3rd crash, and is based on the true details of those who first responded to the 3rd crash. Families and individuals are torn apart, character traits and flaws get exposed, other families break down while other relationships flourish. The center of all of this are two girls, Miri and Natalie who are/were best friends and much of the book is about them and their families. Extremely well done, the book also creates Miri's Uncle Henry who is a reporter for the fictitious Elizabeth Daily Post and between most every chapter there is a story about the crash, about news of the crash, interviews with families, as well as some "columns" about what is going on in the world at that time.What it is not, is a damning indictment of the airline industry or the CAB (the predecessor of the NTSB). Plane travel in 1958 was still new, technology was still not perfect and there was a lot of room for mechanical failure and pilot error, as well as what appears to be one instance of pilot "error" that was done to save lives on the ground. I only gave this 4**** because some of the personal events seem a bit contrived, and what happened to Natalie seems even more unbelievable to me (but then again I am not an expert in how people respond to traumas and tragedies). What it is, however, is a really great read. It is a book you can easily read quickly or put it down for a bit because chapters are divided into segments of stories based on a certain characters. It might not be typical Judy Blume, but that is OK with me and I will be looking forward to see if she reverts to her prior style of book or if she takes off into this new style of writing. I hope she does, because this is a very fine book!...more

title: The Alexandria Link        (Cotton Malone, #2)
author: Berry, Steve*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you are a fan of the Thriller/Mystery/Historical Fiction genre than this 2nd book in the Cotton Malone series is a great read. His first book, The If you are a fan of the Thriller/Mystery/Historical Fiction genre than this 2nd book in the Cotton Malone series is a great read. His first book, The Templar Legacy, was a bit of a disappointment for me but with this book he really has upped the game on both his writing and his plot.The lost library of Alexandria, something that all book lovers and archeologists have dreamed of and wondered both how it really disappeared and what ancient manuscripts were held in this most revered of all ancient libraries. Well, this book gives us the premise that the library has been salvaged and that it now contains such sensitive information that the Israeli's, Saudi's, American's and a secret private organization all want to discover whether the library contents still exist and whether they contain some documents that are so controversial that the entire course of history could be changed. I am not about to divulge more basics of the plot, but this fast paced book takes us from Washington, DC, to Copenhagen, to Lisbon, to England, to Vienna, to the Sinai and, as opposed to his first book in the series, the author keeps moving us from locale to locale and from the many differing parts of this plot that it truly qualifies as a page-turning read. At the end of the book, the author then has about 4 pages of what is real and what is fiction and the reader will be amazed at both how well researched this book is, as well as how much of the plot is based on some pretty interesting public and published information. A good read and one that will have me coming back for more in this popular series - one that now spans 14 novels!...more

title: The Templar Legacy        (Cotton Malone #1)
author: Berry, Steve*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have some of Steve Berry's books in my library and decided to start his Cotton Malone series while on vacation. I was underwhelmed! For an action/adI have some of Steve Berry's books in my library and decided to start his Cotton Malone series while on vacation. I was underwhelmed! For an action/adventure/mystery book I found it a rather dull read, and was unimpressed with the obvious way the book ended. Now this is the first of about 13 books in that series and so I will give it one more chance, since maybe this was an early career clunker. The characters are extremely stale and rather undeveloped and very flat. The plot revolves around the Bible and trying to find clues to some earlier Christian documents by the Kings Templar who are now holed up in current day Southern France. From the beginning it was obvious what the eventual outcome would be and the major discovery of a new book to supplement and explain the inconsistencies in the New Testament. Characters are thrown into contact from page one and to me this book is more of the author trying to impress us with his encyclopedic knowledge of the Templers and church history. What bothers me the most is how a 700-year secret is now so easily unearthed and how this group of people can suddenly become the smartest people in the room! I have recently begun to reanalyze my ratings and so mysteries are rated based on other mysteries, literary fiction against other literary fiction. So for this book I rate as a 3*** when compared to other books in that genre. But for me it was no more than a 1 1/2* on an overall rating scale. Sorry Cotton Malone fans, this really did little for me but I will give the series one more chance....more

title: The Railway Detective        (The Railway Detective, #1)
author: Marston, Edward
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Do you like mysteries? Do you like fast paced adventure? Do you enjoy a quick and fast read that makes you want to stay up all night to finish the booDo you like mysteries? Do you like fast paced adventure? Do you enjoy a quick and fast read that makes you want to stay up all night to finish the book? If so, the Edward Marston is an author you do not want to miss. I read his most recent book about a different detective than in this series, but so enjoyed that book that I decided to go back to his earlier works and this one did not disappoint. This is the first of I think 12 books in his Inspector Colbeck mysteries, and takes us back to 1851 London and the advent of the railroad trains and the first train robbery that has occurred in England. It is a wonderful tale, and it filled with characters that seem right out of the Murdoch Mysteries series I watch on Acorn TV and which now begin their 10th season up in Canada. You have the rough and irascible Superintendent, the sidekick Sergeant and the debonair and intelligent Inspector Colbeck. Colbeck needs to figure out why the train was robbed, how the thieves managed to stage the robbery, who were the accomplices and then throw in a few murders along the way and you have all you need for a rip snortingly good read. I love Marston and he may be the best of the unknown mystery authors. Give him a try. Yes, sometimes things unfold a little to easily but that never seems to stand in the way for a great first book in the Inspector Colbeck - the Railroad Detective - series....more

title: Enchanted Islands
author: Amend, Allison*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Probably a 3.5***Interesting premise. A novel based upon the actual diaries of Frances Frank (her changed name). It is supposed to be a story of her fProbably a 3.5***Interesting premise. A novel based upon the actual diaries of Frances Frank (her changed name). It is supposed to be a story of her friendship with Rosalie Mendel. The book is a quick read, but not a fast read if that makes sense! It starts so very promisingly with the story beginning at an old age home and Rosalie being honored for the work she did in WW2. Frances is her best friend and also in the old age home and laments that she cannot tell her story and nobody knows wha she did. So she tells us the readers. The book is divided into 5 sections and really sections 1,2 and 5 are fast and fascinating reading. Half of Section 4 is very good also. It is Section 3 that brings this book down in my opinion. This is all the "unknown" story of the time Frances and her husband Ainslee were on the Galapagos Islands prior to WW2, and it is all speculation. The book drags here, so much so that one is tempted to just skip over the flora and fauna descriptions, as well as the attempts to make this a spy novel. I learned a lot about the Galapagos that I had been unaware of, but the entire spy premise is a bit hard to fathom, however plausible it might be. What we do see is a woman (Frances) who has lived an interesting life - not sure it was a good life, but it was interesting. We also see someone who gave up many years of her life to part of a rather unique marriage, move to Galapagos and then move back their again after the war. She was basically a loner and her friend Rosalie is not the most lovable character, but that is also tempered by parts of Rosalie's childhood.I would recommend this book for a limited group of readers. It is not for everyone, but there are some portions of the book that are highly enjoyable and give us a glimpse into the life of Frances which was certainly unusual and without a doubt interesting....more

title: My Last Continent
author: Raymond, Midge*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Absolutely loved this book! A book that actually begins with an Afterwards, and then weaves a tale that goes back and forth through Antarctica, as welAbsolutely loved this book! A book that actually begins with an Afterwards, and then weaves a tale that goes back and forth through Antarctica, as well as the lives of the narrator Deb and a man she meets there, named Keller. It is a love story and an ecological story, as well as a an adventure story about a cruise ship that ventures into the realm of Antartica. I am not really a big ecology-oriented person, but this story really hit me as a wakeup call for all of those people who feel the need to be on all 7 Continents in the world and the problems that are created by the new massive influx of tourists who come to Antarctic without the least thought as to how they are affecting the seas, the penguins, and the fish in the seas. We begin with an Afterwards and then go back to a period a few years before the Cruise ship issue that is the main antagonist of the book. From there we swing back later into the narrators life and then back to a more recent period of time. It takes a really good writer to pull this off, and sometimes I have problems with this back and forth time period style, but Midge Raymond pulls it off beautifully.We meet the narrator, crew of the research boat she is on, passengers on that boat, her current lover and past lovers, we see her fractured family and her love of birds that led to her love of penguins. All of this is woven into a tight and compact 308 pages and is a fast, fast read, especially the two longer chapters that deal with the cruise ship disaster. As an avid cruiser, I board those boats and never think about the ecological impact they have on the seas. We hear how they are doing better and better while we are on the cruises, the but she sheer amounts of cruise ships that now ply todays oceans and seas makes me wonder about the impact they make. Again, not an eco-horror tale, but rather a love story that is squarely rooted in the narrators love of Antarctica and the penguins she goes down there to research every year, we follow a dedicated narrator who is brought to life expertly by the author. Great book and one that is a perfect book club read!...more

title: Green Island
author: Ryan, Shawna Yang*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I loved this book. And before I  it, I wanted to say that I have been on Goodreads for over a decade and never really got into having "friends."I loved this book. And before I  it, I wanted to say that I have been on Goodreads for over a decade and never really got into having "friends." This summer my daughter had a college class with Jenny who has the Reading Envy blog and after my daughter raved about her in class I became a Goodreads friend of hers, which begat other friends and thanks to those friendships I saw a lot of interest in this book, Green Island. I was the first person to get it from our library and was captivated from page one. The writing is beautiful. It is not a fast read. No, no. But it is a book you want to slowly devour as the author mixes a family history along with the modern history (since the 1940's) of the island we now call Taiwan.Written from the perspective of the families youngest daughter it begins the night of her birth which also was a night of a massacre on the island, and ends almost 60 years later. By the way the narrator is never named in the book which to me is unique. We follow her family, and her marriage. We go from Taiwan to Berkley and then back to Taiwan. We see Formosa become Taiwan, we see Taiwan go from a Japanese possession to a Chinese possession and then an outpost for Chiang-Kai Shek who became a key ally of the US. And then Nixon goes to China and no longer is Taiwan favored, and it is now the Republic of China, as opposed to mainland China being the People's Republic of China. You see the turmoil of the island and the people through the eyes of this family, as well as the protests of the dictatorship that Chiang created. There is a lot of great history here and I learned so much from this book, and we see how the family suffers and endures over the years.One of the very few books listed as a Best Book of the Year that actually lives up to its reputation....more

title: Miller's Valley
author: Quindlen, Anna
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I had never read any books by this author, but a trip to PA and a meeting with some high school friends brought this to my attention. They were enthusI had never read any books by this author, but a trip to PA and a meeting with some high school friends brought this to my attention. They were enthusiastic over the book and even though it was alleged to be a "woman's book" I decided that their recommendation transcended any genre categorization.Reviews have been all over the place on this book with many not liking it because it was "not like her other books." Two things. First, I have never read any of her "other books" and therefore had no predisposed feelings about the authors style. Secondly, who really cares if it is not like her other books! I heard the same complaint about Edward Rutherfurd's book "Paris" since he did not follow the neat and order historical fiction approach he had used in the past. Get over it folks!!! Authors get bored at being stereotyped as producing one type of book or writing in one type of style. This book was personal for me because the story of Millers Valley is much like my hometown in Reading, PA where in order to have water management and create water fun for everyone, the Federal government bought up thousands of acres of land in the 1970's and created the Blue Marsh recreation area. Water fun with no flooding - of course since Hurricane Agnes hit our area back in 1972 there has not been anything near that type of storm - but we are now blessed with Blue Marsh so that folks from everywhere can come and play on our lake.The author maintains that Blue Marsh was not her inspiration, but we are located about 85-90 miles from Philly - as was Millers Valley - and she manages to use a lot of names and items that are remarkably similar to our area. She refers to a person named Fenstermach - Gee, I grew up with a bunch of Fenstermachers! She had the narrator as a little girl selling corn from her dads farm from a card table - which is exactly like my HS friend Donna Reed did for many a year. The parallels can go on and on, but it would bore those of you not familiar with our area. This is a book about a young girl and her family, a family that lives in a low lying region that the government wants to flood for water management and recreation. It is a story of the family and the region. Yes there are some stereotypical characters - from the Viet Vet druggie brother to the whiz kid narrator who is a complete 180 degree difference from him. But the book reveals family mysteries, family problems and family triumphs all of which are set in and around Millers Valley. It is a short and quick read which is perfect for the topic and leaves us with a 65 year old narrator - Mimi - who has lived a wonderful life and has returned to her hometown area. She recounts the past but does not live in the past (I hope that makes sense). She shows us that we can have our memories and our family secrets, triumphs and tragedies and yet we carve out our own existence is this world no matter who our parents are, no matter what our family history may be, and no matter what happens to our home town....more

title: The Unfortunate Englishman        (Joe Wilderness, #2)
author: Lawton, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Lately, well actually it has been for over a year, I seem to have been drawn to British authors or British novels. And once again on a recent trip to Lately, well actually it has been for over a year, I seem to have been drawn to British authors or British novels. And once again on a recent trip to the local library I glanced to the right on my way out and the cover of this book caught my eye. I picked it up and perused the dust cover and it sounded promising, so it got added to my reading list. Well, it was not a bad read, and I am bored with those who think that only Le Carre can write an espionage thriller about the Cold War. But I felt completely in a fog at the beginning of the book because it referred to action and plot that appears to be a hold over from the first novel of this series. After a few chapters I got a chance to get into the book and there were parts of this that were extremely well written in terms of plot and characters. Not being an expert in Espionage or Espionage Thrillers I am unsure as to a lot of the details in the book, but it appears to be well researched, however some of the double-dealing seems a bit much especially when we get into Scams and old characters from 1947 (this book is set in the 1960's). The ending seemed contrived and hard to believe, from the hotel scene in East Germany, to the escape into the British Sector of West Germany, to the delivery of a special package at the end of the book.Also hard to digest is our protagonists relationship with his wife, who is the daughter of his superior and how he always keeps getting put into situations that just seem hard to believe.This book is not for everyone, but if you are a fan of Espionage thriller books then give it a read. I doubt seriously that I will pick up the first book of the series nor any others the author may write in this series....more

author: Marston, Edward
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was returning my past two books to the local library and had told me daughter, accompanied me on this trip, that I was going to take a break and notI was returning my past two books to the local library and had told me daughter, accompanied me on this trip, that I was going to take a break and not get any library books for a bit and instead concentrate on the books in my personal library. I gave the librarian the two books and headed back outside, and all of a sudden I am confronted by a display of books and smack dab on the middle was Deeds of Darkness. From a distance I thought it might have been a non-fiction book, but as I glanced a bit longer I realized this was a fiction book about home front detectives during WW1. So, I stopped and took a gander at the full cover and inside flap and discovered that this was the 4th book in a series by a writer I had never heard of previously. But the topic sounded interesting and despite my aversion to starting detective novels in mid-series instead of from book 1, I decided to give it a try. Well, little did I know how prolific a writer Edward Marston has been, nor how entertaining this book would become for me. A fast reading, page-turner that deals with a serial killer on the loose in London at the same time as the Battle of the Somme rages on France. This is a book filled with loads of excitement and suspense and does not have graphic and gratuitous violence. It centers on Scotland Yard detectives, and also includes a very interesting anti-war character, along with a top notch plot in which we only find out the identity of the killer a few pages from the end of the book. Very good characters and if you are fan of Murdoch Mysteries up in Canada there are some really similar characters in this book. You can tell that there will be more books to come in this series as there are some domestic issues that have not yet book finished with regards to the detectives, and that a sub-plot with a neighbor and her son are never finished in this book. So, the author has left a lot of the table or the next book of the series. But for now I will begin one of his earlier series about Railway Detectives - I highly recommend this book and this author!...more

title: The Mirror Thief
author: Seay, Martin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have read real junk books that I have rated a 1*. This is not that bad, but I am wondering if I got a copy of a different book from everyone else whI have read real junk books that I have rated a 1*. This is not that bad, but I am wondering if I got a copy of a different book from everyone else who has been raving about this?? It was pretty, pretty bad to put it mildly. First of all the book summaries begins by telling us a bit about the glass and mirror trade in Venice and secrets and mysteries that are happening there in the late 1500's. Then it says there are two other parallel stories that are set in the Venice Beach and at the Venetian hotel. Venice Beach in the 1950's and the Venetian in 2003. So, what do you assume the book begins with - THE VENICE OF 1500's?? Nope - we start at the Venetian then switch to Venice Beach and finally by page 165 we make it to Venice, Italy. By that time I am exhausted from a book that wanders aimlessly, with characters that have absolutely no depth and which I could care less about each and every page.The book becomes work and a book is supposed to be pleasurable. I got to the point where I did not care about the stories, the characters, mirrors or anything else in this book. Some say it is a great mystery and keeps you up all night in a page-turning frenzy. I found it to be the cure for insomnia!Once again, a Best Book recommendation from Amazon that has fallen flat. Just do not understand the ratings and s for this book. But, once again, the good news is that I got it from our local library and did not have to spend a penny on a lousy book!...more

title: The North Water
author: McGuire, Ian*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Well, now that was a great read. It is like Heart of Darkness meets the whaling industry. Henry Drax may be the most realistically evil character I haWell, now that was a great read. It is like Heart of Darkness meets the whaling industry. Henry Drax may be the most realistically evil character I have ever met. So much to write about this short bombshell of a book. Let me begin by saying that if you are not a person who enjoys reading about some foul human depravities then this book may not be for you. While violence and sex (sodomy) are not graphic, they are ever present and yet for some reason this book kept pulling me into its story as I wanted to keep reading to find out what was finally going to happen to this whaling boat and its crew. Very realistic as to the difficulties in the whaling industry in the mid-1800's the author even got the violence and gore associated with harpooning a whale, killing of seals and bears.Really well written and a very fast read, for me, as I finished this in a little over a day. There are few redeeming characters in the books, maybe a few few Esquimaux characters who are described as heathen but are the most humane in the entire book! Even the protagonist, Dr.Sumners has his own problems which trace back to his time served in India, and while haunts him throughout the book.I truly felt that I was reading a better written Heart of Darkness, and the author did an amazing job with this topic. Not for everyone, but for me it was riveting and a book that I will remember for years to come!...more

title: To the Grave        (Jefferson Tayte Genealogical Mystery, #2)
author: Robinson, Steve*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The 2nd book in the genealogical detective series by Steve Robinson. This book continues to follow the exploits of a most different type of main charaThe 2nd book in the genealogical detective series by Steve Robinson. This book continues to follow the exploits of a most different type of main character than we are used to in Jefferson Tatye, man who solves family genealogical mysteries. This book is different then the first one, in that the author fills in a lot of the missing pieces by going back and forth in time, from a current day search for clues as to a womans true identity, to back in 1944 in which we relive a lot of the incidents that occurred through the eyes of Philomena Lasseter. As seems to be the M.O. in all of these books, the family mystery always takes Tayte into harms way and this time it is not different as we begin the book with Tayte seemingly ready to be shot and then go back and find out how he got himself into this predicament. Was surprised at the ending of the book, in that you had a bit of an idea who was behind things, but iti is not until the last few chapters that we find out the motivation for keeping things secret. It is a story of a woman who was adopted and lives in the US and who out of the blue receives a package containing a red suitcase and she hires Tayte to find out who she really is and who her mother is. A bit convoluted in family history, but then again whose family does not contain a bit of convoluted history or at least some strange family members!!If you have never read any of this series they are so very different from the usual detective novels, and while we never really get that close to uncovering a lot about Jefferson Tayte the person, his cases and escapades are always entertaining and quick fun reads. This is the 2nd in a series that has now stretched into its 5th book and I see and long and prosperous career for both Jefferson Tayte and his creator/author Steve Robinson. 4.5****...more

title: Everyone Brave Is Forgiven
author: Cleave, Chris*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The good news is that the author has given us a new perspective on WW2 and those serving in combat as well as those on the home front. Also that the aThe good news is that the author has given us a new perspective on WW2 and those serving in combat as well as those on the home front. Also that the author has British wit down pat.Now the bad news. This is really a dreadful effort. I know it is based on the authors grandparents but I have not seen a book with so many flawed characters and self-centered individuals that one really cares less and less about as the book goes on and on. British humor is dragged out again and again, as all the individuals resort to comebacks and witticisms that lose their effect as they too drag on and on in the book. We have people who fall love at first sight and then do not see each other for years, but the one character is sure that they are in love, so much so that her mother even is also under the assumption that despite only one brief meeting her daughter is going to marry this person. Just beyond the realm of feasibility. Mary is so self-centered and selfish that she constantly wants and takes anything her "best friend" Hilda wants in terms of men and attention. To be honest I am shocked at the number of high ratings for this book as it truly pales in comparison to other fiction books about WW2 and the rash of new WW1 fiction novels.I wonder if the subplot about Mary's helping the black children left behind in London is there to try and redeem her character, but it is obvious by the end that even the black adults do not want her help teaching the children for obvious social reasons. If this is the best that Amazon has to offer as one of the Best Books in May then it is a weak month. Oh, here is one other good thing about the book. I got it through the public library and did not have to pay a penny for it and do not have to throw it out when I finished it....more

title: Before the Wind
author: Lynch, Jim*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Such mixed feelings about this book. For me, it did not live up to Lynch's past efforts and that was a major disappointment. Not sure if it was his wrSuch mixed feelings about this book. For me, it did not live up to Lynch's past efforts and that was a major disappointment. Not sure if it was his writing style or rather that this book really appears to be written to boating/sailing aficionados instead of the general readership. I got totally lost with all the boating phraseology and to me the emphasis on the boating took away from a pretty good story - not a great story. A dysfunctional family that may or may not have received healing by the end of the book really did nothing for me. If it was not a Jim Lynch book I probably would not have even finished it. Now there were good passages in the book and some interesting characters, but to me they took a back seat to the boats and the rigging and the jibs and everything else. Yes there are goodhearted people who work on boats, yes there are some nuts but the entire story just fell flat with regards to the elder Johannson's and Ruby, even though Ruby was one of my favorite characters the little bit she was in the book. Many others have praised this book, but for me it certainly did not life up to the levels Lynch achieved in his prior books which I really loved....more

title: Death of a Red Heroine        (Inspector Chen Cao #1)
author: Qiu Xiaolong
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A really fine debut effort by Qiu Xiaolong who I first heard of on an NPR broadcast. This is the first of his Inspector Chen detective novels set in SA really fine debut effort by Qiu Xiaolong who I first heard of on an NPR broadcast. This is the first of his Inspector Chen detective novels set in Shanghai with this book taking place in 1990 one year after the Tienanman Square protests. The book is both a mystery as well as a look at the cultural conflicts that are going on between the old China and new China, as well as an in the background love story. Chen is the head of the Special Crimes Unit, as well as being a poet and literary intellectual and so you will see throughout this book likes of ancient poetry and stories of their meaning and how everything that Chen seems to do brings up images of the past. At 465 pages the book is at least 100 pages too long, which will keep some from reading it, and I noticed that the authors other books are definitely shorter. Qiu writes with the knowledge of one who grew up in China and is guiding his readers through both a mystery case, plus educating us on the Chinese mentality - something few of us understand (including our elected officials and bureaucrats!).The book also had a very special meaning for me as my father was part of one of the first US delegations every to visit China back in about 1980. He came home marveling at all bicycles on the streets, all the workers sweeping the streets with brooms and all the children in Beijing openly using the streets as their own septic system! I was fortunate to have visited China in 2013 and was just as amazed - but now I was amazed at all those cars and ring roads around Beijing some of which begin about 150 miles from the city. I was amazed at all the western influences there and how a introverted nation has made it to become a major Super Power. Oh, and I was amazed at all the children who still continue to use the streets as their own private bathroom for all their bodily functions. Old China vs New China - definitely change, but yet not all things have changed!...more

title: The Winemaker
author: Gordon, Noah
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Wonderful book about a young man who grows to become in winemaker back in the 1870's. I was recently told that men prefer neat and tidy endings with aWonderful book about a young man who grows to become in winemaker back in the 1870's. I was recently told that men prefer neat and tidy endings with all matters tied up perfectly, as opposed to women who enjoy open ended endings. Not sure if this is true but somebody did a study on this - can you believe that! - and so others may give this a 5 star, while I wanted a bit more. I prefer family generational sagas and so while Josep's story is great reading I wanted to read more about the family, his step-son, his interaction with the village in years to come and his relationship with his brother and sister-in-law. Alas, it is not to be! And as we headed into the last chapter I had my doubts as to how the book would be resolved. And much to my delight the author came up with a fantastic ending. Loved the final scene. I love this authors writing style and have become a huge fan of all his works. The Physician is one of my all-time favorite books but then again that is also the beginning of a family saga. I praise the author for changing his writing topics so easily and gracefully and no matter what style of book he writes, no matter what the topic or story, I will be there reading each and every one of his works. Salud, Noah Gordon, Salud!...more

review: Maybe because it is that I am Italian, maybe it is because I have become WW1 History buff, maybe it is because the wars in the Alps is so rarely discuMaybe because it is that I am Italian, maybe it is because I have become WW1 History buff, maybe it is because the wars in the Alps is so rarely discussed or written about, but these are just some of the reasons that I loved this book. Some folks thought it was boring or could not figure it out. Not sure if they were reading the same book! Pretty easy to see from the beginning this was a book about the Resistance and the life that invaded Northeastern Italy in WW1. A fine book, with interesting male characters. Also loved the grandmother. Some of the other female characters are not as well fleshed out but their part in the story is not as integral as the male characters. Fascinating look at life in occupied land, and also what everyone had to put up with while enemies control foreign soil. Lots of good thought-provoking wisdom from Grandfather and others as to the nature of life, war, etc. Just thoroughly enjoyable to me and a great book club book!...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: For me this was just a wonderful book and fast read. The story of a widower who after one year decided to finally discard his wife's clothing. As he wFor me this was just a wonderful book and fast read. The story of a widower who after one year decided to finally discard his wife's clothing. As he was in the process of doing that he uncovered a charm bracelet that belonged to her and which he had never seen. This is a story about his adventures to discover the meaning of the charms and the secret wife of his wife before she met and married him. Along the way he discovers that his wife was a very different person than she had been the 40 years they were married. In addition he makes discoveries about himself and the new life he needs to live without her. To say a lot more would give away a lot of the plot and the fun in reading and discovering the meaning of the charms and I would not want to do that. But for me it was a well written debut novel, one that touched on a whole lot of human emotions and personally made me want to reexamine my life now that I am retired and what I want to do with my wife and kids while we still have time to enjoy ourselves!! This reminds me so much of another wonderful English book titled "The Unlikely Pilgrimage of Harold Fry" which also is a wonderful book about discovering unknown lives of others, appreciating what we have and a journey in self-examination and redirection. Really great book!!!...more
