The Keeper of Secrets is a fast moving and easy to read novel about the lineage of a very special violAn extremely fine first effort by Julie Thomas. The Keeper of Secrets is a fast moving and easy to read novel about the lineage of a very special violin. It takes us from Germany to Russia to London and impacts upon the Horowitz family - the family that had owned the instrument for over 150 before it was "lost" in 1939. While the author uses many well known depictions of the WW 2, the Nazi prison camp at Dachau, and the eventual way the instrument made its way to Russia, the book flows effortlessly and took me about 2 days to finish it. It is a very moving story with many villains and quite a few heroes. It is a very good book and one that would be a great Book Club book....more

title: The Brutal Telling
author: Penny, Louise*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A fine book by Louise Penny but not the best of her first five. We once again are taken to Three Pines, this time as a result of the death of a hermitA fine book by Louise Penny but not the best of her first five. We once again are taken to Three Pines, this time as a result of the death of a hermit who lived in a cabin in the woods for years. Unlike some of her other books, the crime occurs early in the book and we see Inspector Gamache also early in this novel. But while the book is well written, there is something flat about the characters. We never seem to get true closure or satisfactory answers to the ID of the hermit, how items made their way into his cabin, and worse yet we do not have a really satisfactory ID as to the killer. Unlike other books, this time the focus of the killer is right in the center of Three Pines, and by the end of the the book we have lost two characters that have grown on us during this series of books. We also fail to find out why Gamache's daughter needed to speak with him early in the book and once the Inspector leaves Three Pines to investigate a clue in western Canada, the rest of the Homicide team becomes irrelevant and barely heard from again. This book halted the authors streak of award winners and I can see why. For some reason I feel that at this point she must feel either tired or things have gotten a bit stale in her series. We know it has continued - and I have all the rest of the books to read - so I am hoping that she gets back to her normal standards in her next effort. Part of the problem may be the fact that she has set such an amazing standard for writing and now and then even the best come up a bit short....more

title: Barchester Towers        (Chronicles of Barsetshire #2)
author: Trollope, Anthony
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: OK, I admit that I am an unabashed Trollope fan. I never read his works until about 2 years ago and since then I have discovered his wonderful ChronicOK, I admit that I am an unabashed Trollope fan. I never read his works until about 2 years ago and since then I have discovered his wonderful Chronicles of Barsetshire series. This book, Barchester Towers, is the 2nd book in the series and while we still have some of the same cast of characters as in his first book of the series (The Warden), there are a whole host of new and fascinating characters who join us in the fictional region of Barsetshire. This entire series deals with religious/theological intrigue and politics and in this novel we are dealing with a new Bishop, a new liberal government in London who choose that bishop, a new Bishop's chaplain, a new Warden and a new Dean of Barchester. Whew! Lots to write about and the stories are simple yet in his telling Trollope takes you into the minds and motives of everyone so that good and evil are easily spotted. Told in a remarkably detached and yet completely involved narrator it is a style of writing that has not been seen or use much. Trollope was not quite as popular as Dickens, but his works are much easier on the reader. There is very antiquated language and references to Mythological figures as the narrator equates actions of his characters to the acts in Greek Mythology and one needs to realize that they will have to do some work in order to appreciate these books. For me the best way to read Trollope is on a Kindle or some other e-reader. They have dictionaries that allow you to quickly understand some of words that Trollope uses and which have gone out of use. But this is a minor inconvenience. Give Trollope and his Chronicles a try, and hopefully you, too, will have an wonderfully enjoyable time in the region of Barsetshire....more

title: A Rule Against Murder        (Armand Gamache, #4)

review: Book #4 in the Inspector Gamache series and to me this is the best to date that I have read! Wonderful plot and characters. Not set in Three Pines, buBook #4 in the Inspector Gamache series and to me this is the best to date that I have read! Wonderful plot and characters. Not set in Three Pines, but nearby and so you have some differing characters and see more of Gamache's wife. You also get to see the flaws of the rich and how even some of Gamache's friends from Three Pines have their own flaws that come out as part of the murder investigation.Set in a resort lodge where Gamache and his wife go for an annual wedding anniversary there is murder and a whole lot of anger that bubbles to the fore in this book. Once again, Louise Penny does not even get to the murder until page 112 of my book (some books are shorter in length and so the murder may occur on an earlier page) but it just goes to show the power and capabilities of Penny as an author.To be honest I loved the cast of characters and some of their idiosyncrasies, including a young child named Bean who is 10 years old and nobody knows if Bean is a boy or girl! From the kitchen staff to the gardner to the entire Morrow family that is gathered for their annual reunion it is a group of characters that really draws you in. One of the favorite part is when everyone guesses the jobs of Gamache and his wife. Funny stuff, and just typical of the writing of probably the most talented mystery writer now living....more

title: The Haj
author: Uris, Leon
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Outstanding book. I wish someone had given it to our President and Secretaries of State as Uris really does a fine job in both giving us an operationaOutstanding book. I wish someone had given it to our President and Secretaries of State as Uris really does a fine job in both giving us an operational breakdown on the Koran and a great analysis of the Arab/Palestinian/Israeli situation. Told from the perspective of the Arab narrators this book really does a fine job in giving us a history lesson of the conflict in the Middle East and since it was written in 1984 the characters have also gave us a glimpse of today. I learned so much from this book that I was unaware of with regard to this portion of the world and this conflict. How Arabs and Jews can reach an unwritten compromise and then have the Arabs come out and yell "Death to the Jews" and incite riots. Also there are some pretty damning representations of Arab culture and so I definitely recommend this to one and all.As a historical fiction writer, I feel Uris is a peg below Michener and Rutherfurd and even Follett, but he does voluminous research and it certainly appears that his "history" in the book is backed up by facts. Good read!...more

title: The Second Messiah
author: Meade, Glenn*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: With so many unread books on my library shelves I decided to look for a book and author there that I had not read previously. Maybe because it was at With so many unread books on my library shelves I decided to look for a book and author there that I had not read previously. Maybe because it was at eye level, maybe because it was in the title, but for whatever reason I decided to read The Second Messiah and was not disappointed. It is like a lot of the other conspiracy, man on the run action novels out there, but the fact that it deals with archeology is something that peaked my interest. Not sure that the characters are all that well fleshed out, and it was pretty obvious from the start as to some of the plot twists and turns, but at the same time the book was fast moving, short chapters that kept your attention and kept the different players moving at the same time, and it was just a fun read. The ending was a bit too idealized for me, but other than that I could not really complain about many of the fates that befell the characters of the book. I was very pleased that this was not set up as a series of books revolving around one main character as so many mysteries and action novels tend to be, and because of that as well as other good s I think that I will read a few more of Meade's works - of course it helps that his book The Romanov Conspiracy is also on my library shelf, but I also was intrigued by some of his other titles and plots. Good effort by Glenn Meade and a definite must read for fans of this style of book....more

title: Code to Zero
author: Follett, Ken*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So many recent readers of Ken Follett know him for his epic works about Cathedrals and his Century Trilogy, but early Follett is just as enjoyable,ThiSo many recent readers of Ken Follett know him for his epic works about Cathedrals and his Century Trilogy, but early Follett is just as enjoyable,This is one of his books from the 1990's when he was still concentrating on military books and espionage, This particular book deals with the historically correct, last minute delay of the first American rocket into Space - Explorer One, and rocket that was in its final seconds before launch and was delayed due to alleged high speed upper atmospheric winds, Given that bit of historically accurate information, Follett writes about espionage and intrigue that he fictionalizes about what really really happened that night. He goes back and forth between 1941 and the launch date of 1958 and we meet a bunch of Harvard students who amazingly all become part of the US War effort and many of whom worked for the OSS and the CIA. The book is super fast reading and easy to read - I finished it in 2 days - and the plot is extremely plausible and deals with a character who has awoken with global amnesia and his resulting attempt to find out who he is and once that occurs what was the reason for the cause of the problem. I am not going to say more about the plot but rather just want to recommend this books to those fans of Follett's who may not have read some of his earlier works. Not only can he write epic novels, he can write great spy stories!...more

First of all it is not heavy on prose and settings, but more importantly the author has written a very readable book, with a fast paced plot that, while it has some holes, keeps the readers interest. But it does not detract from the story about a Defense attorney representing a client accused of murdering a preacher. One thing that did bother me was that the author kept referring his characters to other people. review: Another fine effort from Louise Penny, who to me is the best mystery writer of our current era. This time she tackles the duel cases of both a murder Another fine effort from Louise Penny, who to me is the best mystery writer of our current era. This time she tackles the duel cases of both a murder in Three Pines, as well a tackling the Arnot situation that's been in the background for each of her first two novels. I am hoping that the Arnot affair is settled, but even though things seemed to be tidily wrapped up, she left enough room to have Arnot continue to haunt and torment Gamache.The plot of the murder has to do with the death of a person at a seance, and that was a very unique type of mystery that I had never seen utilized previously. It is funny, everyone seems to love the idyllic Three Pines, and yet bad things always seem to be happening there, so that the "under the surface" tensions in this allegedly idyllic and serene location are both puzzling as well as bringing out the worst of many human emotions and behavior.Not sure if anyone else sees the similarity between Three Pines and the town of Brigadoon, not exactly the same sort of locale, but on the other hand Three Pines exists on no maps and most people have no idea the village even exists - which is where I got my Brigadoon parallel.Have Penny's next two books loaded on my Kindle, and have left broad hints that paperback copies of and and all books after those first five would be a welcome Christmas present! ...more

Another typically good effort from Nevil Shute. He loves to bring us the stories of common people that are placed in uncommon or dangerous circumstances and it is very natural and easy to root for that person. Here we have an elderly British gentleman who decides to go to the French/Swiss border to fish just prior to the outbreak of WW2. While there the war breaks out and he tries to return to England. He is placed on charge of 2 children, which eventually goes to 3, then 4 & 5, etc. and this is his story of his attempt to leave France with these small children.I did think that the first half of the book dragged a bit, but the last 150 pages really moved along and was a real page-turner! The book is only 304 pages in length and is a book that I read in a little over 2 days. If you are a fan of Shute you will love this book.Neil Shute has taken his place on my list of favorite authors along with Steinbeck & Michener. Great storytellers!!...more

After reading the first 2 sections of this book I was ready to give it a 2* rating, but then the final section was just masterful and I wondered why the writing was not as captivating prior to that section. It basically reminds me of a narrative of two different peoples diaries which is sort of a weird type of fiction. Obviously the first two sections were about women who hated San Miguel, while the 3rd story was the polar opposite. Boyle returned to San Miguel in a later work and so this island obviously means a lot to him. title: Truth Like the Sun
author: Lynch, Jim*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What an absolutely great book by one of my favorite modern writers. Jim Lynch has done it again with this tale of modern day Seattle, while blending iWhat an absolutely great book by one of my favorite modern writers. Jim Lynch has done it again with this tale of modern day Seattle, while blending in the 1962 Seattle Worlds Fair, as the starting point for Seattle of today. Chapters in the book switch back and forth between 1962 and 2001, as Lynch blends the story of a 70-year old politico who decides to run for mayor after a suicide jumper is egged on to jump by a frustrated driver stuck in traffic due to the potential jumper. We then switch back in time when the politico was the head (as well as the face) of the Seattle Worlds Fair. And into the fray jumps a newly arrived journalist who researches into Seattle's corrupt past and who tries to tie in this mayoral candidate to a 1962 Grand Jury inquest.Just a wonderful way the blend these incidents into a cohesive and fun to read book, While I was pulling for mayoral candidate, Roger, throughout the book, you can easily side with the reporter, the newspaper as it tries to expose the truth, as well as all the others who are being swamped by innuendo and partial truths. One of my favorite parts of the book came when Roger gave the journalist his version of her life story and she was appalled by his implications and innuendos, to which Roger turned it right back on her and said that she was doing the same thing to him.Really a fine effort and let me also recommend Tim Egan's book, Breaking Blue, about another State of Washington corruption books. Both are really well written and deal with completely different events, but the tie with official and police corruption is startling and amazing. I had the opportunity to speak with one of Lynch's publishers a few years back and he was amazed that someone from South Carolina would be reading and loving Lynch's work. I told him that to me it was a no-brainer, in that here was an author who could tell a great story no matter where the setting and since I have not spent a lot of time in the Pacific Northwest I loved his use of that setting in his novels, I guess I have gushed enough about Lynch, but if you have never had a chance to read his works it is worth your while to do so and this short (259 page) book is a great place to start!...more

title: Drinking Coffee With a Fork: The Story of Steve Carlton and the '72 Phillies
author: Bucci, Steve
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: OK, let's be honest. Unless you are a Philly sports nut like I am this book will hold little interest for the average reader. As a Phillies fan who waOK, let's be honest. Unless you are a Philly sports nut like I am this book will hold little interest for the average reader. As a Phillies fan who was 19 way back when Steve Carlton had his amazing season this was a walk down memory lane and for that it is a 5*****. But the writing is pretty poor, the editing worse and there are a lot of disjointed things in the book, Plus the authors digress onto other Phillies issues or baseball issues at the wrong time. Lots of quotes but from the same 8 or so sources. Too much made up play calling by Harry Kallas and the authors try to hard to justify Carlton's season as the best ever for a pitcher. Trust me, unless you lived through this nightmare of a season you have no idea how good Lefty was. He was the only reason people came to the games. The other big thing in this book is that it shows how inept the Phlllies front office was in terms of personnel moves. They traded away so many good players and brought in little in return, They also over evaluated what was coming out of the PCL and their team in Eugene, OR. Lots of bad decisions, but there was one great decision - the day they brought Steve Carlton to Philly! He was great and todays pitchers can learn a whole lot about the game by reading this book and realizing that a pitcher can log lots of innings and pitches and have long and prosperous careers....more

I have read other ers who feel this book is not up to the level of her other efforts, and while I might understand their point of view, you have to keep in mind that this was her first major historical epic and done at a fairly young age and therefore her effort was tremendous. This is my 2nd Susan Howatch book that I have read, the other being Glittering Images, and I am blown away with the detail in her work and how well she weaves the family tale. Sure she uses the Plantagenet family as a guide, but she does an outstanding job with the Castallack family of Cornwall. Each section of the book is narrated and seen through the eyes of a different family member and it is hard for me to figure out which narrator I like the least or the most. It may be the part that is narrated by the mother that eventually wore on me a bit towards the end, as she had continual rags to riches, to rags stories and sometimes she felt very self-centered, but my perception of her even changed when seen through the eyes of other narrators. But in the end it is great family saga, one of saints and sinners, with every callous or wart exposed. Loved it and will start another one of her books in the near future,...more

title: The Jerusalem Diamond
author: Gordon, Noah
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Probably a 3.5. Very difficult to rate this book. No way, shape or form like The Physician which is a marvelous work, The Jerusalem Diamond was a fastProbably a 3.5. Very difficult to rate this book. No way, shape or form like The Physician which is a marvelous work, The Jerusalem Diamond was a fast read but dealt with characters that were totally unappealing to me. The lead character, Harry Hupman did absolutely nothing that would make anyone really like him and yet he allegedly gets a Yemeni woman to fall in love with him and tell us all how lovable he is. Not really. An egotist, and a real showoff to me, Harry is supposed to be on the trail of a diamond that was stolen from the Vatican from the Mitre of Gregory. That is what we are told, and then we have about 300 pages of nothing to do with that diamond! The best parts of the book are the historical fiction chapters that are all in italics. They are enjoyable reads and deal with the history of diamond cutting and with Harry's kin throughout the ages. In between the beginning and end we find Harry trying to shag as many women as possible, and get into a whole different story about an archeological dig with another less than appealing character. So what did I like about it? Well the historical fictions parts were good, the story was a fast read and did not bog down into too many useless details, and the story that is written about is well written. But a whole lot of this did not make a lot of sense to me. I have read The Physician and I guess I expected a bit better from the author. I have 4 other of his books downloaded and still intend to read all of them, he is a very talented writer, but for me the Jerusalem Diamond was an improbably story with unlikeable characters made tolerable only because Noah Gordon is a fine writer....more

title: Circling the Sun
author: McLain, Paula*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Really conflicted over this book. It was a very good and very easy read, but the narrator was, in my opinion, one of the most unsympathetic charactersReally conflicted over this book. It was a very good and very easy read, but the narrator was, in my opinion, one of the most unsympathetic characters I have read about. Not only that her problems seemed to be caused by her own immaturity and selfishness. Beryl's story is compelling in that it began when she was a young girl growing up in what is now Kenya before the start of WW1. Her father was a horse trainer and a rancher, but things changed for her when her mother left the family and returned to England when she was about 8 years old, and so it was just her father and herself until a new woman enters the family. Beryl rebels against any and everything, from the new woman (Emma) to going to school, to not being allowed to continue to grow and roam free as she matures. Beryl is rather headstrong to put it mildly, and eventually even her father lets her down by forcing her into a relationship at a young age that she is not prepared for. But things just keep always happening to Beryl, even though she becomes the first female trainer in Kenya there always is a problem and she loses horses and stables at an alarming rate. Things always seem to happen to her, some due her attitudes and the social structure of Kenya, and some due to mere misfortune (a rusty hinge on a stable door). Beryl is one of those who always seems to attract controversy and problems and I saw little growth in her as a person. But the story is eminently readable and since issues always were right around the corner I had this desire to see what would happen to her next. A novel based on true historical characters and events, I would recommend this and I think book clubs would have a great discussion with this title. The author used many of Beryl's true lifetime events that were in a book Beryl published - and even that was fraught with controversy since many wonder how Beryl could write such a book since she had little formal education. ...more

title: Blind Justice        (Sir John Fielding, #1)
author: Alexander, Bruce
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A very good first entry in the Sir John Fielding Mystery Series. Based on the Historical figure who began the forerunner of the London police departmeA very good first entry in the Sir John Fielding Mystery Series. Based on the Historical figure who began the forerunner of the London police department, this series alleges to follow some of the trials of this blind London Magistrate. It is a very interesting premise, and this first book sets up Sir John as a kindly, beloved and yet authoritative figure, one who takes the narrator of the series into his home after he was falsely accused of theft. Set in the mid-1700's this is a fascinating period of time and the author has done enough research so that you really get a feeling for the time period. This first case is an enjoyable mystery dealing with the death of a member of the House of Lords. The plot is interesting with enough twists and turns to keep the reader guessing as to how Lord Goodhope met his demise. The narrator at this point of the series is 13-year old Jeremy Proctor and that fact helps enhance the mystery and the plot since young Jeremy had just arrived in London when accused of theft. The case is seen through the eyes of the 13-year old, even though the narrator "writes" these tales as an old gentleman. Well done, and already have the next two in the series. I can already tell that I will wish there were more than 11 books in the series!...more

title: The Storied Life of A.J. Fikry
author: Zevin, Gabrielle*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am conflicted over this book and ended up giving it 4*. The book is short, only 260 pages, and is an extremely fast read (no more than a day or two I am conflicted over this book and ended up giving it 4*. The book is short, only 260 pages, and is an extremely fast read (no more than a day or two at tops) and while the author had a very readable style, I sometimes felt that plot development was a bit short and that there were vast periods of time that were skipped over to get to the end.I did enjoy the short synopsis of books before each chapter, and the overall story of the owner of an independent book store. Facts were parceled out throughout the book and so we only find out certain "truths" near the end of the book which is nice, but many of these were foreshadowed in the early part of the book. Of all the characters in the book the two that I liked the most were Amelia who we met in Chapter 1 and who eventually marries A.J. Fikry and the Police Chief who becomes an avid reader after he befriends A.J. Unfortunately A.J. himself is not a very likable character for me, nor is Maya the girl he adopts. For some reason their character development just did not ring completely true and Maya was just not someone I felt attached to - again, others may have a differing point of view and I certainly respect that.But, the book kept me wanting to come back to read more every time I put it down, so KUDOS to Zevin for writing a book that was so very readable and enjoyable. The good parts of this book greatly outweighed the portions that I was not a fan of. ...more

title: The Siege of Krishnapur
author: Farrell, J.G.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Once again Farrell has written a masterful novel. The second in his Empire Trilogy and I marvel at the authors writing style. In my opinion the book iOnce again Farrell has written a masterful novel. The second in his Empire Trilogy and I marvel at the authors writing style. In my opinion the book is a notch below his first book of the trilogy, Troubles. I would rate this one as a 4.5.Farrell is able to show the slow decline of the British Empire, this time set in 1850's India, and does so by rarely having any Indian characters in the book and showing the problem exclusively through the eyes of British, specifically the British East India Company. He also is able to use historical facts and combines them with remarkable symbolism to allow the reader to understand how the Empire began its slow decline that ended dramatically after WW2, although some feel it ended after WW1. He will continue this theme in his 3rd novel, The Singapore Grip, and unfortunately Farrell met an untimely and tragic death, and so we have to be satisfied with this Trilogy. Just an outstanding effort that was based up on the actual sieges at Cawnpur and Lucknow. It is a remarkable effort, filled with many memorable characters and one that will make me anxious (as well as sad) to move onto the third and final book of the Empire Trilogy. Any fan of History and History Fiction should definitely take the time to read Farrell's works. They are just special!...more

title: The Persimmon Tree        (The Persimmon Tree, #1)
author: Courtenay, Bryce
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Still slogging my way through a totally tedious book. Story is OK but there is so much excess verbage and information that the story truly moves at a Still slogging my way through a totally tedious book. Story is OK but there is so much excess verbage and information that the story truly moves at a snails pace. I began this book way back in June and I am still not even close to finishing the book. How slow is it - I have finished 10 other books during this time period. Really disappointed in the book, but I am not going to stop reading it. But I can tell you that when I am finished it will go to the throw away pile. The story is OK, the books pace is too slow and it almost makes Charles Dickens look like an adventure writer! Also way to many pages for what is being written about.Finished!!! What a book. Too long, in my opinion, and yet for some reason I am not satisfied by the end. Three distinctly different sections of the book. First begins with a story of Nick (the narrator) and Anna whom he meets in Java and then proceeds to Nick's escape from that island to Australia. It is rather improbable but it also is the slowest part of the book. Section 2 deals with Anna and her life after Nick leaves and what she does to survive the Japanese occupation. Once again, a long and slow section for me and with a bit of improbability involved in the plot. Then we get to the 3rd section in which we now go back in time and relive Nick's adventures on Guadalcanal and other battles in the Pacific Theater of WW2. This section to me was the fastest moving and most enjoyable and yet I am still have a lot of incredulity over the plot developments. As an aside, Anna tried her best to remain pure and virginal for Nick, but Nick had no such ambition and so I was a bit put off by this allegedly first and purest love of Nick when he seemed to fall in love with and bed every possible woman he met. This book only got a 3*** rating because the last section dealing with the War was pretty good, and the fact that my own father was involved in the Pacific Theater and in some of the same areas as Nick....more

OK so it portrays a bit of the Hispanic culture as seen through the eyes of Esperanza but this book could have been fleshed out so much better and could easily have been 100 pages longer and it may have actually increased its appeal to me.There are certainly some poignant chapters but some events go by so fast with little or no reflection by the author. I know Esperanza is a young girl, and she does have some events that prompt a bit more reflection, but on the whole this is a book that many could have written with short, choppy vignettes from ones childhood.Not what I expected and not worth all the hoopla and ballyhoo. I had read this book a few years ago, and yet the authors tips still are fresh and relevant, maybe more so in todays Digital Society. Trying our best to cut back on clutter, ease our cooking and household schedules, and still try and have it all with one married child, a daughter who is a college Junior and another who will be a Freshman at college, a dog, an elderly and sick father-in-law, and other relatives who live with us. title: Red Notice: A True Story of High Finance, Murder, and One Man's Fight for Justice
author: Browder, Bill*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Fantastic eye-opening book about Bill Browders life and career and about the way he was able to help expose the graft and corruption in modern day RusFantastic eye-opening book about Bill Browders life and career and about the way he was able to help expose the graft and corruption in modern day Russia under Vladimir Putin. This is a book that is a quick read both because of the writing style, as well as for the topic. Page after page of information as to how the Russians looted their own country (via the Oligarchs) and how then Putin turned on them to consolidate his power. Browder used every means at his disposal to accumulate a vast and valuable hedge fund, and along the way go some silent help from the Russian government as they tried to get these Oligarchs under control. Once that happened the Russian government turned on Browder and all of his friends and associates. Eventually they arrested and tortured and finally killed Segei Magnitsky (a tax lawyer who had helped expose corruption and tax fraud in Russia.) That changed Browders life and he became a human rights advocate and the impetus behind US laws are now being used by deny Visa's and seize assets of those involved in the death of Magnitsky. This book has to be read to be believed. And do not miss the unflattering portrait of John Kerry who was more concerned about becoming the next Secretary of State and kowtowing to Obama's demands than in helping advance the cause of human rights abroad....more

review: I have upgraded my rating on this book. The 2nd half of the book I found fascinating and it moved quickly along. There are still way too many names, aI have upgraded my rating on this book. The 2nd half of the book I found fascinating and it moved quickly along. There are still way too many names, and even though we have a chart in the front of the book to identify the cast of characters it gets difficult and time consuming to keep going back and forth. Plus the one characters name is Scala and he is called Scala, Capitano, Congrande, and more. Not sure why the author keeps on using the different names, I assume it is because characters in the book refer to him differently, but for the reader it is a bit confusing.But, a very good story, the authors writes fine dialogue and his action scenes are well written and quite thrilling. Having visited Verona a few time I was transported back to that great town - home of the original Coliseum that was the inspiration for Rome's Coliseum. I have the rest of the books of this series and look forward to reading them after a bit of a break, this book took me a long time to read....more

review: 3.5 stars. After a difficult start filled with Indian terminology every few words, including many Indian words that were not even translatable, the bo3.5 stars. After a difficult start filled with Indian terminology every few words, including many Indian words that were not even translatable, the book finally got down to a pretty good story. I have not yet seen the movie and so I am anxious to see the difference between the two. Seeing that Helen Mirren is in the movie I expect a larger role for Chef Mallory.The main story was entertaining about the Indian families moves until they reached a home in Lumiere, France. Once there you had the predictable, yet quite charming culture clash that led to Hassan working for Chef Mallory. There were some times that the book was detailed as to what was happening and then months/years would go by between chapters with little or no explanation. And by the end you have no idea who, if anyone, Hassan loves. Again, this is a fast reading book and does capture your attention up until the last 50 or so pages when it begins to sputter to the ending....more

This is the 4th book by Boyle that I have read and he just is one writer that I can keep coming back to. Reminds me of some of the similar issues we read about in The Tortilla Curtain, but Boyle just seems to be able to get into all of his characters and point out the flaws, the issues and even the similarities between adversaries. title: The All-Girl Filling Station's Last Reunion
author: Flagg, Fannie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Great Book! Another winner by Fannie Flagg. This time she combines her wit and wisdom by wrapping it around a story of ones identity and the ladies whGreat Book! Another winner by Fannie Flagg. This time she combines her wit and wisdom by wrapping it around a story of ones identity and the ladies who formed the WASP's in WW 2. Filled with humor and memorable characters the books switches back and forth between the present and past, as well as "letters" written by some of the main characters. The story of Sookie Poole is one that really only begins when she is almost 60 and finds out that she is not the person she thinks she is. Characters like her mother Lenore, Marvaleen, Edna Yorba Zorba, along with Fritzi and all the other members of the Jordabalinski family from Pulaski, Wisconsin become friends of ours as Flagg does a wonderful job of telling a story of one lady's crisis and the touching story of the women who helped our Air Force during WW 2 and as a token of out countries appreciation were then ignored and dismissed, with their activities marked "classified" so nobody would fine out for over 30 years what so many brave ladies did to help the war effort. The books makes you laugh out loud as well as weep with sentimentality. It is perfect for any Book Club, and is as good as any that Fannie Flagg has written in her long and storied career. It is my sincere hope that this book will someday be made into a movie, as it is a story that could easily be converted to the big screen. Great job, Fannie!!...more

title: The Bully Pulpit: Theodore Roosevelt, William Howard Taft, and the Golden Age of Journalism
author: Goodwin, Doris Kearns
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am done! I started this book way back in March and 7 months later I closed the cover on this book for the last time. Why did it take so long? Well, I am done! I started this book way back in March and 7 months later I closed the cover on this book for the last time. Why did it take so long? Well, this is truly a weighty book with lots to digest and lots of really small type to navigate. It is a book that, in my opinion, one needs time to reflect upon and digest all that was going on over 100 years ago. So many similarities to today and such wonderful characters. 	The bigger issue is where to begin in this ? The writing – superb but a bit long. The characters – fascinating and yet flawed. The history – so wonderful to peel away some of the mystique that characterizes Teddy Roosevelt. The muckraking press – a lot like today, when the press makes itself part of the story instead of reporting the story. A thorough  would last thousands of words and bore everyone, I am sure.	Let’s start with a very well researched book that contains thousands of quotes. I cannot complain about the authors writing style, but I do think it could have been about 200 pages shorter and had the same effect. Goodwin writes as an academic which does not make for the easiest reading. For me the reader has to keep plugging away and when you do so you are rewarded with a lot of interesting history and you truly get a feeling for the time period.	Roosevelt – a fine US President but with an ego 10 miles long. A man who had to remake himself in order to try and run for President and challenge Taft in 1912. I truly believe that much of the new Roosevelt was an act, and when Goodwin points out that Teddy misread what the Democrats would do in 1912 you see the folly of his 3rd party run. He never expected the Democrats to run a Progressive Candidate like Woodrow Wilson since he says that if he had known that he would never have started the 3rd party. Teddy is an interesting character and there is a lot to like about him (and I think Goodwin really promotes Teddy), the later-years Teddy is not a person that comes across as genuine and instead it is all Teddy, Teddy, Teddy, as he personally destroyed the relationship with Taft.	Taft, on the other hand, comes across as a friendly and wonderful person. Maybe better suited to be 2nd in command, but nonetheless a President who has his principles and gets things done the proper way – no need for executive orders, he promoted bipartisanship and got things done the proper Constitutional way and actually accomplished a lot more than Teddy in terms of breaking up the Trusts and in Land and Water Conservation. But he did it his way and that upset Teddy and his supporters still in the government when Taft was President.	The muckraking press – very important. Teddy used them and they used Teddy. Some of the stories of McClure’s magazine are wonderful and the writers did a great job in exposing the problems in America. But they had an agenda – sound familiar?? After Teddy returned from Africa they almost appeared to goad him into challenging Taft who just was not Progressive enough for the muckrakers. I got a bad feeling about them, however I think that the author does not share that feeling. By the way, why is it always OK if the liberal press pushes and promotes a point of view or candidate, but it is not the same when the conservative press does that same thing??	Who caused many of the later-life issues between Taft and Teddy? Gifford Pinchot who seems like a real jerk since he did not like the new Secretary of the Interior and kept lying and pushing problems with his friends in the Progressive press (muckrakers), along with a Forestry official named Glavis who outright lied to cause problems. Add the press to this who goaded Teddy, and seemed to truly assist his campaign instead of reporting on matters and you get a story of a friendship gone bad, a GOP that was permanently divided and a book that is truly fascinating. 	I recommend this to readers who enjoy US history, but be prepared for a lengthy reading time. The first 250 pages and the final 250 pages are outstanding, but it is those middle 250 that dragged for me. And finally I can say that I have become a fan of William Howard Taft – a great administrator, President, person and judge....more

author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A 4.5**** for me. I have not read Steven King for a long time, but had heard good word of mouth about this book and how it differs from his usual thriA 4.5**** for me. I have not read Steven King for a long time, but had heard good word of mouth about this book and how it differs from his usual thriller writings. So I purchased it over a year ago and there it sat in my Kindle library. Next thing I see is that HULU is adapting the book into an 8-part mini-series and the promos looked pretty interesting. I decided that while I wanted to watch the show on HULU, it would be best if I read the book first. And so I began back in June and, as usual, I had several reading projects and books during the summer and so it stayed barely started until I arrived in Romania and got a chance to concentrate on reading it. Wow!! Great book. Always thought that King was an absolute master with words and that in many of his books the first 200-300 pages were always so well-written and then things always got weird which sort of turned me off. But this book was great from beginning to end. It is a very simple premise - if a person could go back in time could they stop the JFK assassination on 11/22/63 and was Oswald the lone gunman so that if you stopped Oswald then JFK lives, and if JFK lives then the world would allegedly be a better place. And so thanks to diner owner Al Templeton, our fearless time traveler Jake, steps through a wormhole and gets transported from 2011 back to 1958. Both Al and then Jake make trips back and forth in time until Al no longer can do it, and so Jake takes over the task of trying to prevent the assassination. Lots of good stuff in here, and we see how Jake transforms himself into a new persona named George Amberson and changes bits of the past during the 5 years he is back in 1958 thru 1963. He falls in love, tracks Oswald, does detective research, makes some nifty gambling bets with bookies (all of which he wins because he knows the outcomes in advance, but the consequences of winning are different than he had thought), and becomes part of small town Texas. Eventually the day comes and George will try his best to keep Oswald from shooting JFK. But if he does that, then what happens to the future? The book has some definite alternate history tendencies (and an author named Turtledaub has made this a very popular genre), and King takes a whack at this in the book. The last 300+ pages just flew by for me, and the only reason I gave it only a 4.5 rating is that I felt the book was a definite 150 pages too long. Why? Well when Jake/George travels back in time he is given a huge notebook filled with everything he needed to know about Oswald, but while there Jake/George immerses himself in finding out all the minute intimate details of Oswalds life, most of which he really knows and none of which actually advance the plot of the book or add anything to the story. If you want your character to spy on someone then don't give him research on the exact same thing. Now, I can see how this would be necessary for the TV series, and I am sure it is integral in that medium, but to me it is unnecessary excess for a book that is outstanding in all other areas. A great read that I would recommend to anyone and no scary parts!!...more

title: The Potato Factory
author: Courtenay, Bryce
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Loved this book! This is now the 3rd book I have read by the author and I plan to read more. The first I had read was "The Power of One" which is a trLoved this book! This is now the 3rd book I have read by the author and I plan to read more. The first I had read was "The Power of One" which is a truly marvelous book, after that I read "The Persimmon Tree" which was a slow and plodding disappointment to me. And so I came to this book on my Kindle and had no idea what to expect. What I got was a book that held my rapt attention, a book that was a super fast and interesting read, a book that includes two characters that also appear in Charles Dickens book Oliver Twist, and a whole lot of really great history on England, the British legal and penal systen, and Van Diemen's Land, which is now known as Tasmania.We follow the fortunes of Ikey Solomon (Fagin), a young street urchin in London (The Artful Dodger), Bob Marley, Ikey's estranged and vengeful wife Hannah and her children, Mary Abacas who is truly Ikey's love of his life and who turns from prostitute to business woman when her fortunes turn, and one of the great characters I have ever come across who is eventually known as Sperm Whale Sally!This is an eventful book that follows the fortunes and misfortunes of Ikey and how he gets in and out of trouble, along with the journey of Mary who is a mathematical whiz with the device that gives her her last name. We follow them through all sorts of adventures in London and then when they all eventually are banished to the penal colony of Van Diemen's Land, and how this trio act and sometimes interact on the island. It is a wonderful read and is the first of a trilogy, the second being Tommo and Hawk, and for me this was a wonderful and enjoyable read....more

review: Back and forth I go on rating this novel. Many people call it Dickensian, but to me the only similarity with Dickens is in its length, which is about Back and forth I go on rating this novel. Many people call it Dickensian, but to me the only similarity with Dickens is in its length, which is about 200 pages too long. I lost interest in this book for the final 100 pages. There are parts of this book that are well done and which kept my interest, but there are vast portions of the book that drag on interminably. I felt the entire Hobie and Pippa storyline was unfinished, and that the narrators relationship with Kitsy and her family ended up being rushed - something that seems hard to do in a book this length. By the end it was the fact that this book could not hold my interest for long periods of time that led to this rating. The good parts, are extremely well written, but there were just too many throw away and meaningless chapters and sections of the book that made me scratch my head as to how the book won the Pulitzer Prize. ...more

title: The Circle
author: Eggers, Dave
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Very interesting book that really resolves nothing. The author presents the all-knowing, all seeing, all-watching giant known as the Circle and then dVery interesting book that really resolves nothing. The author presents the all-knowing, all seeing, all-watching giant known as the Circle and then does little with the premise. The ending did not zig or zag, and instead we are left with a group of mindless minions following and trying to run the world. This book had a lot of promise and the last 75 pages really ended up dropping the rating.I wonder how an author that brings so much to the forefront can just drop the ball. No solutions, no alternatives, no nothing but the same known issues. So very similar in warnings to Orwell's in 1984.Give this a 3.5 *** and wish it could have been better since things have gotten worse since the book was written. Facebook, Amazon, Twitter, Snapchat, Apple, YouTube, you name it there is too much electronic information. I may need to revert smoke signals to communicate and really do wonder why I have this darn smartphone?? Just so others can track me, or to take photos, or make pithy tweets. I guess the real reason is so that I can carry around my Kindle app and conveniently read books like this while I wait in the parking lots for my wife to finish her shopping!...more

title: Sandstorm
author: Rollins, James*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Whew, what a hard book to rate! This is my first book by Rollins (and for some reason I have a lot of his books in my personal library??). It started Whew, what a hard book to rate! This is my first book by Rollins (and for some reason I have a lot of his books in my personal library??). It started out very promising with a huge explosion at the British Museum and dealt with ball lightning and the possible source of the explosion that was catastrophic in nature. From there we start going into Sigma Force work at Foxwood Casino and then a traitor in the ranks who works for some mysterious group call the Guild. We go to Oman where death, destruction and chaos reign! For me it began as a fast read and the further I got into the book I just wanted it to end fast! Way too many people, scientific details about antimatter, primary water, buckyballs and virgin births. It got way too complicated, and really wove way too much amazing escapes and miraculous events into the story line. To be honest, there was enough crammed into this one book to have given rise to 3 books. Some characters appear and then disappear for hundreds of pages to just amazingly show up again.To me it is a 2.5** book that I will round down to a 2**. Maybe the next books get better and less complicated but this book is just too unbelievable to rate more than this....more

review: I thought this was a wonderfully informative book about a little slice of Americana that none of us knew about until this book was written. Many thanks to the author for bringing this to light, as well as all the surrounding issues that were swirling back in 1919 and during the time period of this book....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A good first novel. Interesting story, not quite what I expected from s, but interesting nonetheless since it does a fine job of switching back A good first novel. Interesting story, not quite what I expected from s, but interesting nonetheless since it does a fine job of switching back and forth between the WW 1 War Zone and the home front in Canada. Ending was a tad weak, and I thought there were a lot of loose ends when it came to relationships. It would be fascinating if the author would continue this storyline with a 2nd book since the war still rages, Angus's relationship with his wife if weak (if there ever really was a relationship), things are never resolved with the schoolteacher or the father, along with Juliette and Paul over in France. There is ample material here for a 2nd book. But taking all of that into consideration it is a very different book about WW1 and that makes it a very good and interesting reading - plus that the book is written by a Canadian which gives us a very new and fresh perspective on the war....more
